Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Protein Functional Sites Identification Using Sequence Variation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Purdue University is awarded a grant to develop novel computational methods that identify functional regions of proteins by revealing mutations patterns, which are constrained by functional requirements. Protein sequences and the tertiary structures have been accumulated in an exponential pace partly due to large-scale genome sequencing and structural genomics projects. An urgent task for bioinformatics includes the development of methods for annotating the flood of new sequences and structures with their functions and the location of sites where these functions occur. Two types of methods will be developed: The first type of methods examine amino acid mutations specific to known functional regions of proteins. The second type of methods identifies positions in proteins that mutate simultaneously in a mutually constrained fashion. A strong advantage of the methods is that it is general enough so that it can be easily extended to predict many types of functional sites and structure features of proteins. The project capitalizes on tremendous efforts and progress made by experimental sequence and structure determination by developing a new generation of computational tools that detect structured variation, rather than conventional conservation, in protein sequences.

The project incorporates the concept of the structured variation into the field of biological sequence analysis. Because the methodology is general and versatile, the method can be applied to other bioinformatics methods, such as sequence alignments, protein structure prediction methods, and single nucleotide polymorphism analysis. Graduate and undergraduate students in biological sciences and computer science will be trained in cross-listed courses among several departments. Several existing programs at Purdue for recruiting minority students and undergraduate students will contribute to broad participation in the project. Overall the proposed project leverages Purdue University's efforts in interdisciplinary computational life science and engineering. For further information about this project visit the PI's lab website at http://kiharalab.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to develop novel computational methods for analyzing and predicting protein functions with consideration of sequence variations and dynamics of protein functions, rather than sequence conservation that is conventionally taken into account. Protein sequences and the tertiary structures have been accumulated in an exponential pace partly due to large-scale genome sequencing and structure determination projects powered by drastic improvement of the underlined technology. In contrast to the new developments of experimental methods for accumulating sequence data, little progress has been observed in computational methods for functional annotation of proteins. Therefore an important task for bioinformatics includes the development of methods for annotating the flood of new sequences and structures and also methods that can provide new insights to protein function.

Under this project, four types of methods were developed and made available to public: The first type of methods were sequence-based function prediction methods, which consider even weakly similar sequences in the sequence database to effectively mine functional information for a query protein. Unlike conventional homology search methods, the methods developed and improved under this project, named PFP and its variants, consider low-resolution functional similarity between weakly similar sequences as well as functional association of proteins that frequently co-occur in a protein. Developed methods showed top performance in the community-wide gene function prediction contests, CAFA. Second, we established computational approaches to characterize and identify proteins of dual functions, moonlighting proteins. Moonlighting proteins are a class of proteins that perform two or more independent functions. Over years, new moonlighting proteins have been reported occasionally, but accumulation of known cases has been slow because they are identified serendipitously by experiments. The analysis showed that moonlighting proteins have distinct functional and interaction patterns from conventional single-function proteins, and the patterns can be used to identify moonlighting proteins in a genome. The work has also estimated the fraction of moonlighting proteins in genomes. To study gene functions, using Gene Ontology, a controlled vocabulary of gene function, for computing similarity and difference of gene functions is an essential technique. To make computation on Gene Ontology easier, the project has also developed a tool, NaviGO, which can easily visualize and compute functional similarity of Gene Ontology. The forth type of method developed, BindML, predicts an interface surface region of a protein that physically interact with other proteins. Protein-protein interaction is essential for function of proteins, particularly in the context of pathways in a cell, and prediction of interface regions helps understanding molecular mechanisms of interactions and provides essential information for artificial modification of protein interactions.

Graduate and undergraduate students in biological sciences and computer science were trained in cross-listed courses and through involvement in the research projects. Overall the project leveraged Purdue University's efforts in interdisciplinary computational life science and engineering.
